ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Spanish improved greatly. A lot of the material covered interesting topics such as witches, fake news, and indigenous communities.
Greater understanding of the Spanish language, how to formulate elegant thoughts, and critical thinking skills
I improved my writing/speaking/reading skills a lot in this class, I feel a lot more proficient in the language after this class.
I don't think I gained anything really from this course. I did not learn any Spanish, though I guess maybe I've become slightly better at forming sentences quickly.
I expanded my knowledge and speaking ability of Spanish and learned about more cultural ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: seminar-style, great topics covered, extremely interesting and fun assignments
Weaknesses: the work for asynchronous days took 1.5 hours

Weaknesses: the asynchronous homework. It could have been structured in a different way

Strengths: the various projects and the opportunity to present in class
I think reading a full-length novel and analyzing it in the class would be very useful.

The only strength I could think of was that we talked about elements of culture in Spanish-speaking countries which was slightly interesting, but the biggest weakness of this course, which outweighs any possible strength, is that we did not learn any Spanish. This course was essentially L5 without the option to choose a topic you like.

I feel like the class had us talk about things at a surface-level, and it didnt feel like we were having much meaningful discussion aside from the essays. The jamboards were a pain to work with, but besides that, the class was engaging and organized well/clearly.
Good content and format. Class size was slightly too big for everyone to practice speaking enough.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Compared to L3, L4 is much more interesting and the discussions are not so focused on how good your Spanish is, but actually what you have to contribute to the discussion.
Yes! I truly love how the Spanish department at Yale is set up, and I want to continue with it as well
Yes, spanish is a very useful and beautiful language, this class is a great chance to become more proficient in spanish through engaging texts and movies.

I would absolutely not recommend this course to another student. I have even told people who tested into L2 to just take L1 so they can avoid this course. I don't think anyone should have to be subjected to L4 Spanish if they are only taking it to fulfill the requirement. If someone wants to become fluent in Spanish and is willing to go through a semester devoid of learning and full of topics they did not sign up to discuss, then maybe, just maybe I'd tell them to take it, but I truly don't think anyone should have to feel the way I felt after each and every section of this class.
I would recommend it as a means to finish the language requirement.
